Hey there, just a friendly correction. The larger nozzle is not primarily used for the exhaust gas flow direction out of the nozzle. The larger nozzle is in order to increase the expansion ratio from the nozzle throat to the nozzle exit (difference in throat area and exit area of the nozzle). This allows the engine to convert more thermal energy (heat) from the combustion process to kinetic energy (velocity of the gas flow). This equates to more overall thrust and increased efficiency.

The reason we can't use these large nozzles at sea level is due to the pressure losses described in this video. If pressure leaving the nozzle is lower than ambient pressure (outside air) there are pressure loses that play a negative role to thrust.

This being said, there is a component of losses to due non axial flows, it is not the real reason for the large nozzle though.

as always thanks for the "show", checked out the those models, very cool, bit out of my price range at the moment but ill be keeping them in mind. Since so many of my favorite youtubers are always so kind as to answer questions a few occured to me while watching your cast.
1, I know after launches they dump the 2nd stage into the ocean, with the high cost of putting stuff into orbit wouldn't it make sense to find an "out of the way orbit" to leave the 2nd stage until it can be recovered and recycled. I would imagine they would have at least a few thousand liters of fuel/lox that would be useful plus all the material actually used in the construction of it.... heck there is a "space" rocket engine that could be strapped to a asteroid to move it to a more useful orbit.
2, I love rockets and space and can't believe we haven't moved farther along in devoloping it as a place to work and live. I watch at how much money we spend on developing different rocket systems and don't understand why no one has done much work on building a electromagnetic launcher. I see the US military has a em railgun that can shoot a (if i remember correctly) 7kg shell at 5000 kph. sounds to me the technology is there just needs to be ramped up a bit. Everything i have ever read on the subject suggests we would immediately go from 1000s a kg to $s a kg . I know there was a proposal to build one for under 20Billion with a suggested price for a mass only (no people) for 10 billion. Is there no one actualy working on this? it seems like a total no brainer, heck Mr. Bezos could do it all on his lonesome. If you know of anything please let us know.
Anyhow 4am, thanks again and until next time.

Your assumption @ 30:22 is correct..., well not really the turbo pump exhaust but rather the gas generator that drives the turbo pumps. As ambient atmospheric pressure and density, decreases with altitude, the GG exhaust that ends just past the heat shielding, start to spread out and is not drawn into the main exhaust flow as it is in the lower atmosphere. LOL it always creeps me out to see it inching up the sides of the rocket under the landing legs if attached once above 50,000’.

The (new) second stage cameras look like they have artifacts of MPEG4 encoding, which is like JPEG plus incremental frame compression. However, the lenses seem to be intentionally degraded with vacuum grease or scouring. This technique was used to reduce resolution on some Hollywood extreme close-ups to obscure skin pores. Like cataracts, the dark areas are obviously overlayed with scattered light.

The single mVacD engine, besides the huge nozzle, also has the pre-burner/turbopump exhaust injected around the perimeter of the nozzle. This increases the efficiency. (You can see the tapering donut-shaped plumbing welded to the nozzle.)
